title: Rupert Murdoch has a plan if Lachlan and James are dud hires, it involves $US44m
text:
Illustration: John Shakespeare.
It is good to see that the rage over Bronwyn "Chopper" Bishop 's choice of carriage has not been distracted by the news that Rupert Murdoch 's boys, James and Lachlan Murdoch , will potentially pocket a combined $76 million a year at 21st Century Fox.
You have to pay up if you want the right talent.
In the words of Fox's lead director, Rod Eddington : "The board has long been focused on succession and we're fortunate to have two very talented executives in Lachlan and James to take this company into the future."
And don't worry, Rupert has included a clause to cover the possibility that his two kids are not up to scratch.
Advertisement If their respective employment contracts, which run through to June 30, 2019, are "terminated during the term without cause or by the executive for good reason" before June 30, 2018, the lucky boys will each cop a $US22 million cash lump sum.
From July 1 that year, the boys luck out with the cash lump sum reduced to $US11 million.
Murdoch's got talent.
How do you get yourself a job like this you ask?
Well, why don't we ask James Murdoch.
In 2002, he offered Time magazine's Asian edition a very candid insight into the rigorous process that saw him picked for his first major CEO role at dad's firm – Star Television in Hong Kong.
In a London restaurant just before Christmas 1999, he got a phone call from his father. They talked for a while, then Rupert said: "Think about China."
Days later in New York, James caught up with Dad.
"Do you like Chinese food," he was asked.
"And that was kind of it," James told Time . "It had been decided."
In the tink His billionaire days may be well and truly behind him, but you won't hear Nathan Tinkler complaining that he couldn't get arrested in this town.
It appears that a Supreme Court judge in South Australia who issued the arrest warrant is very keen to hear about the collapse of Tinkler's thoroughbred racing empire, Patinack Farm. And he wants it straight from the horse's mouth – so to speak.
It is understood that the probe by Patinack's liquidators – which was due to commence on Monday – is expected to centre on a payment of about $5 million allegedly made from Patinack Farm Administration to another Tinkler-group company.
At least Tinkler is not facing jail time in his new home of Singapore – Changi Prison is not easily confused with Tinkler's rented pad on Sentosa Island.
Pub brawl It was always going to get ugly as the witching hour hit at listed pub operator Lantern Hotel Group.
Despite removing most of the previous board last month with a stick of dynamite – and instigating a thorough review of the business – the current directors appear to have been caught unawares when one of its prize Western Sydney assets, the El Toro Motor Inn, was disposed off for the sum of $24 million on Friday.
Given that some of the aggro centred on the feeling that the pub assets were being run at sub-optimal levels, the sale of a prize asset at this juncture was obviously a concern.
No mention was made of the sale when the company sacked its CEO on Monday with immediate effect.
CEO Russell Naylor – who had already been removed from the board as part of last month's purge – was sent packing with a six-month payout in lieu of notice.
The payment is in line with the new services agreement with Naylor's consultancy, Naylor Partners, that was agreed with the previous board before it was turfed last month.
Naylor's departure removes the last tentacle of Lantern's largest shareholder from its executive suite and board room.
Naylor is a director of Kiwi group Pyne Gould, as was Lantern's recent chairman, Bryan Mogridge .
The close ties between Lantern and Pyne was the other reason for the ugliness with other major investors.
It will be interesting to see if Lantern continues to use Macrossan & Amiet Solicitors if the legal side of things gets ugly. The most recent annual report revealed that Naylor's brother is a partner at the firm.
